Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Towards an Ecosystem of Simulation Models and Data; 5th INFORMS Simulation Society Research Workshop; University of Durham, United Kingdom; July 31 to August 2, 2017

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this workshop is to bring together researchers and students from the domains of digital simulation and data science to accelerate the concordance of these distinct but overlapping technologies. The ubiquity of data from diverse sources (sensors, social networks, Internet of Things) and evolving data-science technologies for machine learning, visual analytics, and collaborative modeling and analysis present great potential for transforming simulation practice, and both domains are crucial to the understanding and further evolution of data-driven decision support systems. As data become a ubiquitous resource, and simulation models become increasing complex, the simulation community faces major challenges and opportunities in both exploiting available real-world data and in extracting insights from the massive data sets produced from large-scale simulation experiments. The convergence of science from both research communities holds promise for tackling major research questions in both fields, such as overcoming barriers to data-driven, online simulation, assimilating and correcting data from multiple sources, simulation input uncertainty, and incorporating machine learning innovations into simulation. This award will support the participation of graduate students who will become the next generation of leaders in the simulation community.

This workshop will be held at the University of Durham in the UK from July 31-August 2, 2017. It is organized by three leading simulation researchers and brings together intellectual leaders from both simulation and data science around such topics as data assimilation, data farming, online data-driven simulations, robust simulation, database technology, metamodeling, machine learning, model calibration, and collaborative modeling and simulation. The workshop organizers have identified eight topic areas, and focused groups of researchers will present and reflect upon emerging research in these areas and identify important directions for future research. The workshop will be broadly promoted through major professional societies such as the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS), the American Statistical Association (ASA) and the Association for Computing Machinery (ACM). Results will be widely disseminated through a special issue of the ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main objective of this project was to support travel for graduate students to attend the 5th INFORMS Simulation Society Workshop, “Towards an Ecosystem of Simulation Models and Data,” held in Durham, UK. Travel support was targeted towards students who otherwise would not have been able to attend the workshop.

Summary of workshop: The goal of the workshop was to promote fruitful interactions between the data science and ORMS simulation communities. Research activity at the interface of these two communities has been growing, but this was the first workshop aimed explicitly at bringing researchers from both communities together for the purpose of scoping and advancing research in this area. More broadly, this workshop was the fifth edition of a biennial series of research workshops organized by the INFORMS Simulation Society. The broader goal of this workshop series is to bring together small, focused groups of simulation researchers to reflect on timely and important simulation topics of interest, allowing deeper exploration of these topics than is typically possible during larger conferences.

Intellectual Merit: Data is becoming a ubiquitous resource via social networks, sensors, and the Internet of Things. At the same time, simulation models are increasingly complex, detailed, and large-scale. In this new world, the operations-research simulation community faces major challenges and opportunities both in exploiting available real-world data and in extracting insights from the massive data sets produced from large-scale simulation experiments. Evolving data-science technology for machine learning, visual analytics, and collaborative modeling and analysis has great potential for transforming simulation practice. In the other direction, melding data-centric analysis approaches with simulation models, which embody hard-won, deep knowledge of domain-specific first principles, can lead to predictions and decisions that are more robust than in a purely data-driven approach.

 

The workshop promoted interdisciplinary collaboration between the data science and operations-research simulation communities, accelerating the development of overlapping technologies that have started to occur over the past several years. The workshop featured sixteen invited speakers and five contributed poster talks. Throughout the workshop, the simulation community was encouraged to develop technologies for (1) exploiting existing data to make simulations more flexible, dynamic, and accurate, (2) managing large amounts of real-world and generated data to make the modeling and simulation process more efficient, and (3) extracting insights from large scale simulations that produce massive amounts of data. The data science community was encouraged to incorporate simulation technology in order to improve the robustness and accuracy relative to pure data-centric approaches. The meeting produced recommendations for research directions and priorities in this evolving interdisciplinary field. Research priorities included collaborative modeling and simulation, formulating simulation models, exploring simulation output data, data and simulation optimization, real-time data, data-management technology for simulation, evolving role of simulation in a data-driven world, and applications.

Broader Impacts: Funds from the project were used primarily to support travel expenses of graduate students to attend the workshop. Two students were supported from these funds. These students gave poster presentations and were able to dialogue with leading researchers in a one-on-one manner. Regarding outreach to the public, the full program is posted on the website of the INFORMS Simulation Society at http://connect.informs.org/simulation/conferences/workshops/2017. Also, a special issue of ACM Transactions on Modeling and Computer Simulation will be dedicated to full versions of selected papers presented at the workshop. Finally, regarding broader improvements to society, the research collaborations and technical advances arising from the workshop will potentially yield significantly improved methods and systems for supporting the design and operation of engineering and service systems in a variety of application areas such as healthcare, manufacturing, retail, urban infrastructure, agriculture, and defense.
